* Lamb Kebab - Oh, but this, this dish. Whatever flavor the bolina was lacking in, the lamb easily made up for, and was surprisingly tender and juicy too, to boot!

* Chicken Qorma - Well, okay, this dish as well, adding yet another explosion of flavors. I did recall the chicken being a little dryer than I'd like, but, that's oftentimes the case with white meat isn't it?

And if the dishes aren't enough on their own, they have some table sauces lying around for that extra dash of flavor.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Another smaller, and slightly cramped venue, with tables places closed enough that only a handful of them are actually accessible if the place is full.

Bathroom - Didn't try.
author: Johnny W.

description:
had the combo kabob plate (beef and chicken) that came with a finely chopped yum cucumber salad 
and the  Qabili Pallow
(Basmati rice with lamb shank topped with carrots and raisin) - OH so yummy. the lamb fell off the bone. 

they were both gluten free and AMAZING
service was friendly. we went on a saturday afternoon around 1:30 and it wasn't crowded but also not empty. 

also had the mint yogurt drink - refreshing. 

this is my new favorite place downtown!

delicate flavors
perfectly cooked meats
gluten free
author: Win H.

description:
Excellent little hide away. When I got here at 6pm on a Thursday, no one was here. By the time I left at 8pm, this place was beaming with energy.

I ordered the lamb shank as recommended by many and it was super tender. The Afghan bread was a bit more hearty, dense, and thicker than its Indian counterpart Naan. Also a crossover between pita bread and Baan. Worth trying!

Great service.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
#88
Quaintly situated on San Francisco's busy Geary street there is a narrow restaurant serving some of the best Afghan food choices--I love this place!

We had a rowdy party of 6 (leaving from an event around the corner) and it was everyone else's dinner time, so the place was a bit crowded.  I never mind waiting for a table in a crowded restaurant, it usually foretells of great cuisine.  The server got our table together after a pretty short wait, but none too soon, we were all hungry.

I, myself, have never eaten at De Afghan Kabob House before, but I PROMISE, I will return.  One of our companions had eaten here several times before and promised the food was good.  It smelled amazing, the crowd looked happy eating their food, and I think I believed that the experience was going to be one to write about!

We ordered:
Bolani potato and leek bread with a delicious yogurt dipping sauce
Cilantro pepper green dipping sauce (of which I almost drank it was so super good)
Chicken with shirazi and two kinds of rice
Tikka meat and chicken combo with shirazi and two kinds of rice
FREE Baklava dessert...FREE!!!

We enjoyed each other's food, and our own as well.  The joy of eating with a group of people is the ability to eat off of their plates too ;)  My chicken was some of the most moist and well seasoned chicken I have ever had the pleasure of eating.  The shirazi complimented the food perfectly, as did the rice sides.  I ate so much food I needed help getting out of this little, narrow restaurant.  

The service was superb, the food was stellar, the venue is inviting.

Stephani Smiles for De Afghan Kabob House ;)
author: Stephani M.

description:
Ok, so the first time I dined here, I was all about it. Small, family-owned joint, on Geary and Van Ness.

My taste buds broke.

The borani badenjan was epic. I could've eaten eggplant for weeks. The yogurt sauce was perfect, the tomato sauce thick and flavorful. The bolani was the perfect combination of flaky and toasted on the outside, and filled with steaming and perfectly seasoned potatoes on the inside. The bolani and I were all up in that yogurt sauce. For dayz.

Only thing I didn't like was that the prices aren't on the menu. I like to know these things.

We ordered takeout tonight.

Disappointing:/

The sabzi and badenjan were just ok:/

Damn, maybe it was just the chef tonight? Gotta knock it down to 3 stars:/
author: Gabriela W.

description: I went to De Afghanan Kabob house for dinner. The restaurant itself is cozy, but it didn't seem too difficult to walk-in and grab a table. I placed a pick-up order so I can't speak to service, but the food was delicious. I ordered the lamb kabob plate, and the beef kabob plate. The price is a little steep (approximately $15-$20/plate) and the quantity of food is borderline (you're not going to get a food coma), but the most important thing is that both plates tasted amazing. You're going to get a couple pieces of meat, over a bed of rice (I recommend paying extra to get the seasoned rice), potatoes, and a small salad. I will definitely be back. Enjoy!
author: Ken C.

description: Came here at 2:55, they refused to serve us because apparently the cooks left? Although it says they close at 3. Extremely disappointing. Drove all the way from Sacramento.
author: Zohra M.

description: Besides the fact that the restaurant owner did not seat me and my wife and our small kids due to it being close to 9pm, therefore, only letting us order take out, I have no complaints about the food. We ordered two orders of chapli kabob entrees.  Each entre came with two large patties, large portion of rice, salad and something vegeterian with pinto beans. Overall, we were pretty satisfied.  A giant thank you to the gentleman who packed two complimentary Afghani chai for me and my wife.  Super nice!
author: Khalid M.

description: The pumpkin challow was a bit plain, but the combination kabob was good.  Good service.
author: Kathy K.

description: I love this place. Great food and great service. The owner ( wais ) is always around when you need him. Little pricy but compared to other great restaurants it's fair. Highly recommended.
author: Storai J.

description:
Good, casual place with delicious lamb kabobs and hot tea on a cold & rainy night. Our waitress was so warm and welcoming. Overhearing this was my birthday treat for my friend, she gave her a delicious Firni dessert on the house (Afghan pudding prepared with milk, rosewater, cardamom and pistachios).

We chose this restaurant since it's so close to AMC Van Ness movie theatre (just 1 1/2 blocks away), but will definitely come back for the food and hospitality!
author: Angelique V.

description:
Stumbled upon this place by accident. It happens to be walking distance from the hotel I was staying in while in San Francisco. Loved it so much we visited twice while staying here!! The first night we order the combination plate...delish!! I've never had such tender and seasoned meat before!! It was amazing. Second time we came I ordered the Teeka Beef plate.......even better than the first time!!

Minus the fact that the venue itself is so small and hard to find seating when full, it is WORTH THE WAIT!!!!!!

We are devastated we have to leave because we know we won't find kabobs this delicious back home. We will for sure be visiting again whenever we are back in town!
author: Jacqueline C.

description: What a fabulous food ! They have best kabuli pullaoo I ever had in my life ....! Strongly recommend !!!
author: Usman G.

description:
If there was a way to give 6 stars, I would award it without reservation to this amazing Afghan restaurant.  They recently opened their location in San Francisco at the expense of shutting down the one in Berkeley and I am sure those East Bay denizens are now in extended mourning.

It's a no frills place with amazing food and great service.  We had pretty much everything on the menu: the bolani, the spinach, the eggplant, and the triple kebab.  Everything was just flat out spectacular, seasoned perfectly and bursting with flavor in each bite.  Nothing was greasy or salty, the flavor was from fresh ingredients and expert cooking.

We had leftovers and were walking down Van Ness and a homeless person asked me for the leftovers.  Normally I would have said yes but I had to say no because I wanted the food for myself! I did give them some money to get their own food so don't hate me too much. 

Check this place out before it gets too popular which, by how brisk business was tonight, means that won't be too long.
author: Saminda W.

description: The best! No introduction needed - just perfect! Upgraded from triple to quad kabob (I just made it up) lol!! Awesome - lamb just melted in my mouth! Perfect blend of herbs and spices - yummy - the best hidden gem in SF.
author: david d.

description: I am familiar with Afghan cuisine.  We have an excellent restaurant in San Carlos and Burlingame.  So this was my first visit outside of my regular place.  The menu had a variety of items, but less than I am used to.  We tried Bolani - Leek & potato-filled pastries baked on a flat pan served with yogurt and cilantro chutney and triple kabob.  What they don't tell you on the menu is they put chili flakes in everything.  I am not one for spicey, so it ruined the meal for me.  If they had not put so much chili flake, the food would have actually been pretty good.  The meats were juicy and tender, but spicy.  The bolani was on the bland side, but the sauce did help.  Service was fair at best.  Parking is street parking, so it's the roll of the dice for you.  Prices were okay.
author: Andrea B.

description: Simply because the service was rude rude rude. Never had such bad service at such a great restaurant that I Love. Male server didn't serve menus until over 5 minutes after seating us. Water wasn't served until another 15 minutes. No exaggeration. And I hate leaving a bad review but it was horrible. He never once checked on us and got every single order wrong. The food was good but honestly they are short handed and one person could possibly man down the small restaurant but he was not fit for the position.
author: Ahroso A.

description: Very good meats. I would recommend the mixed grill option, as the marinade/heating method make it amazing. Rice is solidly above average, and other dishes tried were above average. I was very impressed and will hopefully come back as the kabobs were outstanding.
author: Nick J.

description:
I ordered the Lamb Platter ($16) and was pleasantly surprised by just how tender and how big the lamb shank was. The rice, carrots, and raisins were just decorations for the centerpiece of roasted, perfect lamb. I couldn't believe the size and I had to share or else I couldn't have eaten it all by myself. 

The Beef Dumplings were also good, but the Lamb was Amazing.

We also got the Doh. Definitely acquired taste - it was yogurt in very pure form, very liquid with cilantro infusion and slightly sour.

Will be coming back again for the kabobs and bolani!
author: Shelley C.

description:
Yes! The chicken Kabob is probably as good as it gets and is definitely deserving of a "WooHoo!".

Before I digress, I just want to say that it was one of the best chicken kabobs I've had ever had (bar none); soft and succulent, it was simply bursting with flavors! The seasoning was just right and you can tell that it was marinated for quite a while, and cooked quickly on high heat (for it to be so juicy). The green cilantro/pepper based sauce/chutney compimented the kabobs perfectly. The sides included aromatic long-grained rice, seasoned and cooked perfectly, in two different styles (or maybe one was brown rice, and the other white; I couldn't tell). The shirazi, or the eastern version of a pico-de-gallo made a perfect match for the rice and the juicy hunks of chicken.

We did, however, start with the Bolani. A flat bread that was stuffed with, in our case, potatoes and leek, served with a yogurt dip. I loved it! It was similar to an Indian "Alu Paratha" and I happen to love the alu paratha. As you could tell, that dish was a carb-country-fare on a plate. The bread was a little crunchy and a little flaky without being as leavened as a puff pastry (but tending towards that very slightly), with the soft steaming moist stuffing; dunking it in the seasoned yogurt, it was magic in my mouth!

I also tried a bite of the dumplings and they were *really* very delicious too. But having tasted the kabobs, I'd be hard pressed to order dumplings instead; but I'd be willing to, nay, love to, split a plate of kabob and a plate of dumplings with a dining companion --- if only I can fool them into not diving headlong for the kabobs.

I had a glass of the "Dogh", a savoury yogurt drink that was seasoned. It is akin to an Indian "salt" lassi; but I'd venture so far as to say that it is very close to a "Butter Milk". I love butter milk. But it may not be for everyone.

Next time, I wanna try the "sheer yakh" ice-cream. 

At $61 for the Bolani appetizer, three entrees, and two drinks, the check for $61 (+ tips) was pretty reasonable.

I will be back.
author: Umesh T.

description: I have not been this to location yet! But I am extremely happy that is now near by. I used to drive from Daly City to Fremont. You must try this place out. The food is amazing. Congrats on the new location! The beef is my fave!
author: Mara C.

description:
Manly man meals. 

With the most restaurants per a capita in America, you would think that SF has a plethora of choices when it comes to restaurants that offer both quality AND quantity. Sure, there's Asian restaurants that give ginormous portions and charge as little as a happy ending in Thailand by a ladyboy (in USD) but the quality tends to be shit. 

Enter De Afghanan Kabob House. Opening last Friday, they took over the old Cilantro and Best Burrito taqueria (down the block from Mel's Drive-In); making it their fourth location in the Bay Area (two in Fremont and one in Livermore).

What makes De Afghanan Kabob House a solid 5 star restaurant is they offer a delicious, stick to your ribs, manly meals with blue collar prices that doesn't compromise on quality. Hello halal meat! Thank you for making me feel better about inhaling a cow. *pats muffin top*

A great appetizer to share, the Bolani ($9.99) is a thin, crisp yet soft flatbread stuffed with potatoes and leeks. It was very satisfying especially with the tangy housemade yogurt sauce: http://bit.ly/1kHgqJE.

A must order is their Triple Kabob Combo ($16.99) which was good for sharing unless you can eat for two: http://bit.ly/1b2lll6. Enough protein for days, all three chunks of chicken, three chunks of teka beef and two chaplee beef patties were very well marinated and cooked. The meat was incredibly tender and insanely flavorful with a nice herbaceousness. Even the chicken breast was as tender as perky boobies. The teka beef was my fav of the trio because the flavor was explosive and the meat melted in my mouth like a fine steak from a high-end steakhouse. 

All platters are served with rice, salad, and warm Afghani bread. The combo platter, however, was served with both Challow and Pallow which were addictingly good. Challow is (white) rice with cumin seed and canola oil. Pallow is (brown) rice with cardamom, cinnamon, nutmeg, black pepper, cumin and canola oil. If you're going to indulge in carbs, this is the way to do it--with tasty, aromatic rice. 

Don't be fooled by that mountain of orange rice in the Quabili Pallow ($13.99) because underneath all those carblicious carbs was an incredibly tender lamb shank: http://bit.ly/1fmmb7W. Loved the addition of raisins and carrots for a sweet crunch.

Even though we had enough leftovers for another couple, I had to try the Sheer Yakh: Afghan ice cream ($6): http://bit.ly/1fmmgbR. The vanilla ice cream with the rose water and cardamom was really refreshing and helped cool our palate from the complimentary Shornakhod: garbanzo beans and potatoes in tangy chutney sauce: http://bit.ly/1ez285n.

Service was pleasant and the food service was pretty prompt considering there were only two staff on the premises at the time. 

There's only 6 four-tops and 1 two-top table so the restaurant is good for small parties only: http://bit.ly/1gzALfR. Reservations are taken (I overheard another table having them). 

Most of you know how damn picky I am and De Afghanan Kabob House definitely ranks as the BEST Middle Eastern restaurant in SF for me. 

Please don't ever change, my fav manly man meal provider...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Food was tasty and the wait staff attentive.  Should've stuck with kabobs. Instead I ordered a dumpling dish that was more like ravioli. Flavorful dish, just not what I was expecting.  My friend ordered a lamb rice dish that she enjoyed, but the yogurt drink was incredibly strong and she barely drank it.
author: Ana G.

description: This was my 3rd time I have been to this restaurant and I got nothing but bad service especially yesterday I took my wife to lunch because she wanted to have some muntu and as you can see from pictures what I got served from this place a plate with a few dumplings and a drop of yogurt sauce lol it's a joke then the other picture is from khyber pass restaurant in Dublin where they really serve afghan food you guys be the judge anyways the owner of the restaurant has no customer service what so ever I was treated like I'm the one that served them the food OMG I felt like I was in the wrong restaurant like the food did not look nothing like the there pictures on there menu lol I told him why isn't my plate of muntu looking like that the owner responded I don't how other afghans make there food but we make ours like this if you don't like it go somewhere else wow!!! I sure did never would I ever go back to this fake afghan restaurant ever again!!!
author: Robbie N.

description:
Triple kabob FTW.

Sri's special: 6 pieces chicken, 1 piece chaplee.

I eat here at least 3 days a week. Have come twice in a day.

 All you  need to know is the chicken is epic. Go get it now. Eat it there so it's actually hot.

Use the green sauce.

It's all about the food.
author: Sri P.

description: Shocked and disgusted by the horrible treatment we received at this location last night!!! If I could give them ZERO stars, I would!! After a long and tiring day in the city, my family was craving some really good Afghan food. We've eaten at the Fremont restaurant before (Don't know if these locations are related), so we were excited to discover another location in the city. My husband and brother in law dropped my sister and I off at the restaurant, along with my two children, to find parking. We walked in and told the waiter/owner (whoever he was) that we were a party of six. The restaurant was on the smaller side and was a seat yourself, but we wanted to see if he could help us figure out seating.  He told us right away that he didn't have space for us to sit together, randomly proceeds to tell us that they were out of "Bolani," even though we didn't even ask him anything about the menu yet. And then tells us that maybe we should go somewhere else and gives us a name of a different restaurant. We thought his comments were weird (as who tells a customer to check out another restaurant- most owners are courteous and friendly and would try to make arrangements). We decided not to take offense and sat down at the open table, figuring seating will eventually work out. We were hungry, it was late, plus we were looking forward to eating there all day. Luckily a table for two opens behind us, and we decided we would just split our party to sit separately between these two tables. A few minutes later another family walks in. The owner quickly comes up to us, tells us to "get up" and that he is giving our table to the other family. We asked him why (since we were there first and already seated) and if the other family had reservations. He told us that he doesn't do reservations but he "had the right to refuse service to anyone he wants and that he does not want to serve us." The other family looked embarrassed and upon realizing what was happening offered to sit somewhere else, but the owner insisted they take our seats. He basically kicked my sister and I, along with my two children, without any explanation and humiliated us in front of a full restaurant. We were so shocked and never experienced anything like this before. Who asks seated customers to leave, especially when there were no issues with us.  We didn't know why he did this as we had no issues with him. It seemed like he wanted us out as soon as we got there. Our husbands hadn't arrived yet from parking so we were forced to wait outside in the dark, with two children in an area that we were not familiar with. What a rude and shameless person he was. Who kicks women with children out in the dark without any reason?? He obviously lacks customer service skills, lacks passion for his business and doesn't care about his customers. My husband finally arrives and we explained what happened. He went inside to politely speak to the man and the guy had no explanation, except that "he had the right to refuse service to anyone." Of course he had nothing to say, no reason, no apology, as we gave him no reason to do this to us. He's either racist or lacks complete professional skills to run a business. I do not recommend this place to anyone. He said he's related to the Fremont location, which is such a bummer. We should've realized from the start that he didn't want us there and saved ourselves the waste of time. At least we ended up enjoying dinner at another Afghan restaurant near by called Helmand Palace. That place was beautiful and had amazing food and knew how to treat their customers!!
author: Deeba P.

description:
This place is great! The actual restaurant is small and it might be hard to find room for slightly larger groups.
The food is very good and authentic. For the appetizers they have a crepe like dough with potatoes in it ( forgot the name) 
If you are really hungry try their trip kabob ( chicken, beef and steak ) ! Done forget their green chutney sauce.
author: Jad A.

description: I love trying out new cuisine and I was not disappointed with this place! The place was not very big, but it's seems very popular! The kabobs were amazingly delicious!
author: Geraldine C.

description: Great place! I never tried Kabob before and the beef one was incredible!! The service was very nice too! I had a nice first experience with Afghanistan food! I'll be back!
author: Melinda M.

description: Omg i am too glad i came across this restaurant randomly. Food is authentic and really good here. This was our first time here and we will definitely be back. Ordered the chaplee kabob and quabili pillow.
author: Shanzay H.

description:
This place has balls. And, thank goodness for that! Thank you for being brave enough to prepare meat with slap-you-in-the-face flavor - a rare find when it comes to Middle Eastern cuisine in the city. The waitstaff is also incredibly friendly and go out of their way for their regulars. 

The lamb kabob is so good, I feel slightly brain-dead on first bite every time. I am Armenian, and as lamb naturally flows through my veins, I can judge this meat with confidence.

5 stars? More like, 'Final Supper' status. Bless you!
author: Alexis H.

description: Came here last night for a casual dinner with a friend and the food did not disappoint! It's a cozy restaurant with a simple menu of incredibly flavorful food. We shared the triple kabob and the eggplant appetizer (served with warm, crispy afghan bread - YUM). Portions were perfect. I can't wait to go back!
author: Mileen Z.

description:
Food was ok. Lamb was over cooked, mantoo  was overdone, pumpkin bolani was inedible, though the potato was ok. 

Worst of all, I was in a group of 4 and when we gave her 4 credit cards to split a $70 bill and the owner/waitress refused to charge 4 credit cards saying that it was against her "policy" to only accept 2 cards from a table of 4, which is ridiculous bc if we came here alone, she would have to charge 4 cards. So it put us in a terrible inconvenience of trying to transfer money between us because she couldn't bear the extra credit card charge which every retailer has to bear to do business in the city . She was incredibly rude about it. Needless to see, I won't be coming back or taking my friends or clients here.
author: Amanda C.

description: A nice Afghan restaurant, Food light , Local rice is very tasty. I know the staff well smiling, Have an easy access. I'll come again
author: Erdal Ç.

description:
Great food and wonderful, warm service!

I remember when this place used to be a Mexican food place and was excited to see some new cuisine take over. 

We had the Bolani, dumplings, and triple kebab plate (chicken, beef, beef patty). I'm generally not a fan of ground beef but the patty was delicious and well-seasoned/spicy. We had both the potato and pumpkin Bolani and both were really good. 

All in all a really positive experience with great food. I will be back!
author: Semuteh F.

description: Love it! Can't wait for them to open a second location in San Francisco. I always am craving their food!
author: Zebra A.

description:
Bolani, bolani, bolani.

Lamb kabob, lamb kabob, lamb kabob.

Badenjan, badenjan, badenjan.

Yum.

(See my review of the original in Fremont for more)
author: Archana P.

description: The food was great! But the guy waiting on us was just wayyyy too cool for his job, his attitude was snobby. We told him that we  had never been to an Afghan restaurant, he didn't even tell us what he was bringing to the table as he brought the food. We had to guess because he was bothered by our questions. Ruined the experience.
author: Hilla T.

description:
I've been coming to this restaurant since they were located in Berkeley. Imagine my surprise when they picked up and closed shop in Berkeley and relocated in SF, down the street from my house. Ecstatic, was the word. 

The food was pretty good, and fairly cheap. I ordered the Borani (more on this), Triple Kabob, Combination Kabob, Quabili Polo and Firni.  The Triple and Combo Come with a lamb, chicken, chaplee and chopan kabob, so we had a chance to have everything. The food is great. But I ended up having a little trouble with the borani. Online, its a pumpkin dish, which isn't bad I assume, but I wanted potato. So we called and got potato instead of pumpkin. Mind you, it isn't anywhere on the delivery menu, but you CAN order potato leek Bolani if you call the restaurant. In fact, I think most things are available for delivery, but NOT on the delivery menu. Call the restaurant to confirm. 

Can I just say the Firni was SO YUMMY!? It's a rice pudding with rose water, sprinkled with cardamom and pistachio over the top. It was soooo good, I might go there just for dessert some time. 

In short, good food, good prices, albeit, confusing ordering process. Order what you want with the restaurant directly.
author: Zehra A.

description:
Love this place! I highly recommended trying it out if you're looking to get your healthy veggies and protein fix. Everything was really delicious. I love the casual, easy vibe of the small restaurant. Service was speedy, simple, and sweet. 

You really cannot go wrong with the Triple kabob platter. It came with chicken, tekka beef, and chapli, veggie salad, and two kinds of basmati rice. The chicken kabobs were my favorite -- so juicy, tender, and flavorful. Mantoo dumplings were soft, flavorful, and yummy. 

Everything tasted so clean and fresh. I love my middle eastern and Mediterranean cuisines. I really appreciate their use of whole ingredients for flavors like cilantro, mint, and lime. Clean and healthy eating for the WIN baby!
author: Ellen W.

description: Great food every time! Little restaurant no nonsense customer service. The chicken is always juicy.
author: Cassandra C.

description: Great food and service.  We had the lamb and beef kabobs.  Boloni was great also.  We're eating here once a month for sure!
author: Hafa C.

description: Anybody who hasn't eaten here is seriously missing out! The kabobs here are more tender than at any other Afghani or Persian place I've ever eaten at! No joke. I didn't know it was possible to get kabobs to taste this good. The combo comes with tri tip, chicken, and chaplee kabobs and the best I've ever had. Very reasonably priced and worth every penny.
author: Sheena N.

description:
Worst customer service!! Almost bordering on discrimination. 

Tip: invest in a clip board like every other civil restaurant has and write down names so you can attend to your customers in order.

Food-- order chaplee kebab or the potato stuffed bread or the chicken tikka. You can't go wrong with that.
author: Majid M.

description: The food here is really good. Only downside is the inconsistent customer service. If you call to order food, it just depends on who answers the phone and what mood he is in. I've ordered a couple times from here and half the time they are unwilling to customize or substitute-out foods, even if there's a dietary restriction and EVEN if you're willing to pay for the inconvenience.
author: Nina N.

description: We came to town on a chilly summer day. After reading Yelp reviews, we decided to try this place and was happy with the choice. We had Qabili Pallow and Lamb Kabob. Both were delicious. The rice itself had a nice taste. Their warm home-made bread was good. The lamb was juicy and tender. Food came fast and staff was friendly. Next time, we'll try the Afghan ice cream.
author: Le H.

description: First time ever trying Afghan food..so how the heck would i know how good Afghan food is suppose to taste, right? I'm pretty sure i or most wouldn't be too crazy about "real" Chinese food, so our opinions are based on what is served in this country...with that said, I am a fan of Afghan Bbq! At least at this place. The right amount of spice and whoo, huge portions. Will definitely try again. Hopefully, they continue doing what they do and not change.
author: Orlando J.

description:
Totally agree with Hen's review. I originally discovered this gem in Fremont and would go all the time. I had no idea that De Afghanan Kabob House opened in the city, as well.

The boyfriend and I decided to get takeout delivery from here. They were pretty slow with OrderAhead's App (took nearly 2 hours for delivery when we were quoted 60-75 minutes), however, the food was still piping hot and delicious. 

We got the Combination Kabob with Chicken, Beef & Chapli (soooo good) which comes with cilantro chutney (it has a kick in it!), Basmatic rice, and Afghan brad. We also tried the Mantu - Afghan Pasta filled with ground beef and topped with meat sauce & garlic yogurt. Overall, we really really enjoyed these hearty dishes and the two orders were perfect for two people. We spent about $45 for the two of us.

Overall, the food here is delicious and never disappoints- I think we'll have to try the dine-in experience next time as I heard this place has more of a restaurant-feel than the one in Fremont!
author: Veronica S.

description:
I tried out this place yesterday because my sister recommended this place! I am a big fan of spicy food so I ordered the chicken kabob and requested it to be spicy. My oh my was it spicy and delicious! The entree came with some brown rice, a spicy soup (contains garbanzo beans and potatoes), fresh tomato and cucumber salad, and a side of two slices of bread. 

The entree, however, is a little pricey. It came with about five little chunks of chicken. Parking is terrible! It took me a good 30-35 minutes of just trying to find parking and it was not close by at all. I had to walk a good few blocks to get there. The place itself is pretty small and thank goodness I came at a time when it wasn't too busy.
author: Linda C.

description: Awesome food. Very nice service. The place is small and gets crowded too soon. If you want to try come as soon as it opens to avoid waitng.Would love to come back.
author: Bon Vivant R.

description: I tried one of their combo plates that included a skewer of chicken, lamb/beef, and a spicy ground beef patty. My favorite turned out to be the chicken skewer. It was moist and very flavorful. The service was very attentive and and the bread that comes with the meal is also very good. It is a little pricey, but it seems like most Middle Eastern restaurants in the city are around this price point.
author: Binh P.

description:
The food is delicious
We had:
1- chicken kabob- chicken was moist and delicious, we had a mixture of white and brown rice
2- lamb kabob- very very good
3- lamb shank - delicious
4- Bolina- was paratha like with potatoes and scallions, wish the filling was much more 

Service- meh, we received one of our dishes 10 minutes after everyone else received their food, which sucks because we were done and my husband just started his food, had to take it to go he didn't want to be the only one eating. 

Had to flag our waitress down to get the bill, oh and there was only one other party in the restaurant besides us. Shame. 
Service leaves lots to be desired.
author: Tahima B.

description: Is the best, you have to try this amazing restaurant, those kebabs are delicious and they are nice guys
author: Amirhossein H.

description: The best food ever,service excellent, restaurant clean , Over 15 times eating here still very tasty.
author: Eyad D.

description:
I LOVE this place. I come every weekend for their Chaplee Kabob, which is a delicious seasoned ground beef patty with scallions. My boyfriend loves their Tekka Kabob for the tender high quality beef. 

The meat is served with two types of rice and a tomato cucumber salad. The brown rice has a lovely flavor from meat broth. There are sauces tableside but honestly I find the dishes so well-flavored that I never add them. 

This is a family run shop and the servers are really sweet and courteous. I see some reviews about slow service on here - but I've never had any issues. 

Overall, hands down one of the best meals I've had in SF. My one complaint is that the restaurant is not closer to my house or I'd be here a lot more!
author: Susie S.

description: This place is definitely a one of those hole in the walls that you would probably just walk by if you didn't know about it.  Overall the place is clean and the food is great! Ordered the Bolani (potatoe) and the triple kebab.  Out of the triple kebab my favorite was definitely the chicken, but their beef was also cooked to perfection! Consumer beware: their bolani and ground tenderloin contain chili flakes so those with weak resistance to spicy food be careful!
author: Brian H.

description:
The food was great, however the service was terrible.  After sitting down, the waitress served us water with ice and when we asked her to give us water without ice, she snapped at us very rudely. She said "if you wanted water without ice, why didn't you tell me earlier". 
This behavior from the  waitress was absolutely unnecessary. She should know that not every customer wants water with ice. People don't go to restaurants for the food alone but the experience and we couldn't enjoy the rest of our dining experience at the restaurant, as we could sense the animosity from the waitress. Never had I felt so unwelcome in a restaurant.
author: Ifthekar C.

description: Went here with a friend and we split the Borani Kadoo and the Quabili Pallow. The Borani Kadoo was a delicious pumpkin dish that has a great yogurt sauce and spices added. I would get this a second time if I went again, it was delicious. The Quabili Pallow was very tasty and the lamb shank had plenty of good meat on it. The raisins and carrots added a nice flavor, and the dish was simple, tasty, and filling.
author: Nathan B.

description:
We phone ordered take away on Super Bowl Sunday. 

The order was ready right as promised. $32 for a bolani appetizer (way too much for 2 people) and a triple meat combo (lamb, chicken and a meat patty - served with breads, 2 kinds of rice an 2 salads.)

All in all too much food for 2 people, The meats were tasty - the chicken was super tender and the meat pat tie was well-seasoned.

It was all probably a bit too spicy for my tastes, but that is on me. Good luck to this little business.
author: Amy W.

description: This place is really great! The meats were extremely well seasoned - everything was tasty, fresh, good quality, not greasy, and a good value. We devoured everything. I would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Been here twice now and both times I absolutely loved the food. Ordered the qabuli palow which had a lamb shank in it, the meat came off smoothly and was cooked very well. The chicken Kabab plate is also very good and cooked all the way thru but still juicy with flavor. 
The food didn't take too long to be served either. The place is small but clean. Makes you feel more comfortable to eat there knowing the bathrooms are really clean too especially for a place in the city. 
There were 4 of us and we needed the bill to be split even though it was written on their menu that they only allow payments up to 2 different credit cards because it can turn into a hassle the waitress still split it for us and charged us all separately which was nice of her.  Definitely one of my fave places in SF.
author: Amara M.

description: Outstanding! Had our first meal in the city at this place and it was awesome! Ordered from both the familiar side of the menu (kabobs), and the unfamiliar (regional dishes). Every bite was excellent. Three dishes was plenty for four hungry people. Even the bread was special. Service was friendly and gracious. Walking back to our hotel late at night was a little dicey, but worth it!
author: Di H.

description:
I never had Afghanistan food previously.  It was very foreign but good.  To me the Kabobs seemed sort of greek.  I had the lamb shank. It was tasty.  

I tried the house specialty yogurt drink.  I couldn't drink it.  The flavors were too strong and too foreign.

If you've tried everything and want something new this is a good place to try.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Good food but goddam awful service. Any dining experience is a combination of different elements but food and service are the key elements to mine. De Afghan delivers on the food, tasty and greatly seasoned Kebabs but unfortunately the service makes the experience fall flat. I've been about 6 times at the place and as the popularity increases their service becomes unbearable. The problem? A mix of popularity, lack of tables and aloofness. If you come with no reservation be ready to be greeted with a standard response of you'll table be ready in 10 minutes.... Yeah.... More like an hour or so. Why does it take them so long? Quite simply there's at any point two or more tables ready to pay but no one approaches them until the wait line becomes unbearable. So be ready to be standing in a small room for a long long time. 

This restaurant got all the ingredients to be a GOOD local dining but until they improve their service I'm not going back.
author: Angel J.

description:
Came here and both times are awesome. The place is quite small so it might be tricky for big groups.

This is my first time having Afghanistan food and it was amazing. First time I got the combo plate which contains 2 types of rice, beef patty, chicken kebab, some beef cubes. The beef patty was so well marinated and seasoned with a slight spicy kick. Chicken kebab was insanely tender and juicy, which totally blowed my mind.

The second time I just got the beef patty by itself with rice. We also got the lamb with raisin rice dish. Being a sucker for anything that contains raisin, it was good. The lamb is not terribly lambs which suits my taste. However the portion of the lamb was not big at all despite it was flavorful and tender.

I will definitely come back as much as I can.
author: Ruxin H.

description: I see 300 reviews already say this place is great, and I came here to say the same thing. Amazing food, very friendly service, feels like a family place with a talented cook. Only problem is that I always want to order the same thing over and over because it's so good. Then I order something new and want to order THAT over and over. Other places have come and gone in this location, and I hope they stay forever.
author: Super C.

description: Small, casual. and inexpensive, but great tasting food and great service. I try to come here any time I go to the AMC theater on Van Ness or to a show at the Great American. Their tea is one of my favorite (non-alcoholic) drinks in town.
author: Jesse G.

description: De Afghanan SF, in my opinion, has the absolute best kabobs that I've had in the city. Not a huge menu, but that's great,  because what they do,  they do very very well. I'm a huge fan of the triple kabob with seasoned rice. Simple food, cooked really well,  with great flavors. Spicy green sauce is delicious, with a nice kick to it.  If you're wondering why the 4 star review if i love it so much, well it's because I've been to the De Afghanan in Fremont,  and that one is better. Not by an enormous margin, but it is, slightly better. Also, for those of you non meat eaters,  they have an eggplant dish,  that even I enjoyed (not into non meat entrees, but it was pretty good) Anyhow, I recommend giving this place a try,  or even a few. Start with the kabob dish with rice, then venture out into the menu. I've had several items,  and they've all been good. I'll post pics next time (last meal didn't make it to the photo shoot.)
author: R A.

description:
Stopped by with a couple of friends for dinner.
Had the kabob, the beef was better than the chicken but did enjoy both.
The service was on par with other places, however, they do rush you out when you are done in order to rotate the tables.
This is not a place to hang out for 2hours.
author: Omario R.

description: No change from my previous visit. This is still a good afghan restaurant. The customer service is good. I finally tried the Mantoo. It was also very good. The meat was fresh. The dumpling was soft and flavorful. It was a cross between Italian ravioli and a Chinese dumpling.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: Awesome!! The greatest Afghan restaurant I've been to. I tried Chicken Kabab and Quabili Kabab.
author: Connoisseur B.

description: This place truly delivers authentic Afghan flavor. Customer service was outstanding. Super friendly and welcoming place. This is a must try here in the city. Will definitely comeback!
author: Mariana C.

description:
I just went to this place to have some food. I stepped in, the place it's empty, just one person in a 4 people table and the server it's right at the kitchen talking with a person that had a to go order.
I waved the server to let him know if I could have a sit. So he moved his head telling me that was ok.
I walked in and I choose a table. He told me in a very bad way, to sat anywhere else but there cause that one was his table.
Can you believe it? 
How rude someone could be?
This place must be those ones where the owner wonder how having such good food the place is not working. Well Mr.owner this review must give a little clue.
author: David C.

description:
This place is fantastic. My goal with any Afghan place is to compare the Kabuli Palaw to others I have had. This place is awesome in that the dish is served with the lamb shank laying across the top. Most others I have had simple have chunks of lamb in the dish. The meat off-the-bone is so tender and juicy, whereas the chunks seem to dry out.

It is BYO, which is nice, and service is great. The prices are very reasonable. Definitely worth a visit if you're after very flavorful food...
author: John F.

description:
Love this place, I've been here 2 times and the most recent one was on the first day of Ramadan. I came too early before iftar and she was cool with me sitting there and not ordering for another 30-40 minutes since at the time no one was inside. 

20 minutes before iftar and the place is packed and my friend and I ordered our kabab dishes which took exactly 15 minutes to make. She gave me dates to break fast with and the food was out right on the dot. I got the combo with chicken, beef, and chapli all very good and only for $16. With each entree dish they also give a small bowl of chutney, beans, and potatoes which is really good. You definitely get your money's worth here. This place is a block away from Van Ness so its not in the heart of Tenderloin.
author: Daanyaal K.

description: I flew into town to see a concert and was hoping to find a close by Middle Eastern food. I definitely hit the jackpot! It was only 1/2 a mile from my Hotel and I was drenched from the rain, but it was well worth it. I had the eggplant appetizer and Combo Kabobs with Chicken and sirloin. Absolutely delicious and will be going back next time. Service was great and staff were also friendly.
author: Mehdi F.

description:
Simply outstanding. Truly home cooked style Afghan food. The chaplee kabob is the best. Delicious, savoury and hearty.

Cozy little restaurant, friendly service. Great experience. 

Highly recommend.
author: Maryam Z.

description:
WOW. 

My mouth is literalyl watering as I write this review.
Flavorful BBQ that's not at all spicy but nothing like mediterranean or South asian flavors. This place is legit and go. Run. get there by 9:30 because they dont offer seating in the restaurant, even though they close at 10pm. Really nice guys, but honestly, the food is so good, you pay attention to nothing else. 

WOW.
author: Farwah N.

description:
The best Lamb Kebabs, Lamb Shank, Ice Cream, and Bakhlava I've ever had in my life. I'm originally from Azerbaijan so I know what good lamb and bakhlava tastes like and this is seriously the best. I've been to dozens of middle eastern places around the bay area and even in places like London and Baku but I've never tasted lamb that was so succulent and flavorful.

The ice cream is not too sweet and has pieces of cream in it and the bakhlava is served warm and melts in your mouth. The sheer chai is a must, it's like a hot chai latte flavored with honey.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Food at this place is really good. I have tried almost all the items on the menu and there is really nothing which doesn't taste spectacular. Personally, my favorite is chaplee kebab. It looks like a burger but it is ten times more delicious than an average burger. The spices are on point and the service is very friendly. Prices are also very reasonable. Definitely try their baklava and black tea, as well.

Even though the restaurant is kinda small, they also try their best to accomodate big groups.
author: Cem A.

description: We just got to our hotel and were famished. Turned the corner and saw this place and walked right in. Tried out the sabzi, triple kabob and mantoo and left mindblown. Each and every bite was amazing. Oh and the saffron rice with the kabob - wow - best flavor a. This place knows what they're doing. Totally delish. I'll be back!
author: Shveta M.

description: Finest Afghan food I have ever had. We had Kabobs, which ranged from very good for the sirloin to amazing  for the chicken. Looking forward to returning for the Mantoo. Convenient for date night due to proximity to the movies.
author: Sean S.

description: The bomb! Chicken and lamb kebabs with the special raisin rice were winners. Bolani tasty too.
author: Sam H.

description: First experience of afghani good..I mean food. Amazing! Had the vegetarian option of pumpkin and rice and afghani bread. The green topping sauce they provide to each table was tangy and delicious! Highly reccomend
author: Amanda S.

description: Worst customer service .. rude .. not fit to be in hospitality business ....owner has no respect for his customers. Visiting from out of state and he ruined our night completely with his arrogant and rude behaviour. He needs to learn how to speak to his customers. This place isn't worth all the hype.
author: Honest O.

description: This restaurant isn't even worthy of 1 star! Very rude and arrogant owner who knows nothing about hospitality and how to treat his customers with respect. Asked him a few questions about his menu and he throws major attitude- very rude and unprofessional!!
author: Rad A.

description: Great kebab my favorite kebab in sf.  My favorite eat there 3 times a week.. I am recommending 100%.  Try the beef.  Absolutely delicious!
author: Tri T.

description: Visited this place with some folks from the law school today. Unbelievably delicious, friendly, fresh, great place. The kebabs are fantastic, but don't miss the Quabili Pallow if you like lamb.
author: Alexander A.

description:
This place is a real delight! The only reason it's doesn't get 5 stars is the actual restaurant is a little bit rough on the inside but authentic I would say. 
Now the food, simply fantastic! Some of the best meats and kabob style food you can find anywhere, I'm talking world. The herb green sauce is almost "crack" like, it really makings you want more and more. The rice is perfect and the potato salad is something new for me. The person that runs its is a real treat and makes you feel welcome.
Grab your friends, bring a couple bottles of wine and enjoy a really wonderful meal.
author: Brook M.

description:
Is Afghan poised to be the breakout cuisine of 2014? I don't know what that means... and who talks like that anyway? All I know is that the few morsels I've had of it, I liked, whether it's Helmand Palace on Van Ness (review: http://bit.ly/1nwaCkz), Kamdesh in Oakland (review: http://bit.ly/1hWYRV7), or Ariana in New York (review: http://bit.ly/Qmubkp). This could be the best of the bunch, and ironically (food snob that I can be), it's part of a chain based in the Little Kabul section of Fremont. Ever read "The Kite Runner"? Yep, that neighborhood. I've never been to the one down there, but my guess is that this location does not offer as authentic a decor. No, the fairly spartan ambiance is in line with its Tenderloin location, including the door that couldn't remain shut after you close it. But the food pictured in the laminated menu looked appetizing and our inhibitions subsided.

We first received our bread basket of Bolani, a native flatbread freckled with sesame seeds (photo: http://bit.ly/1hWWxgS) along with a tasty dip that mixed chickpeas and diced cucumbers in a green sauce that I'm guessing was made from cilantro (photo: http://bit.ly/1hW2REg). Already on the table were jars of spicy and mild sauces that we also applied to the bolani (photo: http://bit.ly/1jT7Jth). I think the appetizer that came next was my favorite dish of the evening, the $6.99 Barani Kado, chunks of sautéed pumpkin seasoned in garlic and pepper with mint and a drizzle of homemade yogurt on the top (photo: http://bit.ly/1gISAHf). It was a nice combination of savory and sweet with the pumpkin providing just the right texture for a most enjoyable consumption. Jamie W. ordered the $16.99 Lamb Kabob, six big chunks perfectly tender from the grill accompanied by two different rices and a fresh side of chopped tomato, onion and cilantro (photo: http://bit.ly/1ljroGx).

That was quite satisfying, but I ordered their Triple Kabob for the same price. I got a combination of chicken, tekka beef and chaplee  This appeared to be the better deal for the insatiable appetite since I received three large chunks of the chicken, three of the beef, the same sides and a hefty ground sirloin patty mixed with scallions and crushed red pepper (photo: http://bit.ly/1jhKDJT). The chicken was surprisingly moist and the beef was juicy, all of it quite tender and well marinated. But the standout was the chaplee because of the mix of seasonings mixed inside the meat. It was especially good with the table sauces. The server was quite cordial and informative about the dishes. She appeared to be the only one serving all the tables. It was really good eating, and I wouldn't hesitate to come back for more of that pumpkin. Maybe Afghan food is the breakout foodie fad, but what do I know?

FOOD - 4 stars...succulent kabobs, but it's the Barani Kado that stays in this glutton's memory
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...not much of it but it's clean
SERVICE - 4 stars...terrific server really showed off the food with pride
TOTAL - 4 stars...a strong four stars for this Afghan outpost of a popular South Bay chain
author: Ed U.

description:
Was super excited when this place opened up.  Heard great things about the food, though when I got take out and had a view of the kitchen, I was not super impressed.  Th amount of things that were literally thrown into the microwave, made me question both the prices and the food handling.  Take out was super slow, even though everything I ordered was tossed into the microwave, and I called 10 minutes in advance.  

The food was good, and I am trying to put my anti-microwaving feelings aside, since I think this is probably a common practice, that I just saw here in person due to the smallness of the space.
author: Jennifer L.

description: We walked in about 30 minutes before closing and the rude waiter told us "no more" and walked away. Meaning, they aren't taking any more customers. Seriously?!
author: R K.

description: The bread here was sooo good!! The food and service was fantastic as well. We got the kabob mix and loved everything.
author: Jen H.

description: Delicious food but the portions are small... so small that a combo kabob  meal was not enough for my 9 year old daughter.... and a bit over priced...
author: Khalil N.

description: Great hospitality, yummy food, and a small simple restaurant. Perfect spot before a movie at the AMC Vanness theatre, would definitely come back. I had the kebab combo and the chicken was amazing!
author: Kassaundra G.

description:
Weekday night, 2 people

De Afghanan is a good spot on the edge of the Tenderloin serving Afghani food (who would've guessed?) that seems like a close representation of what you'd find in Kabul.  The place is not tiny, but not giant either.  If you come at peak hours, you'll be standing around waiting, so it's up to you whether you want to wait inside or outside - they could be doing a better job providing seating considering the number of people waiting when we left.  With one server taking care of everyone, service was also a bit slow.  

Our food was good, with one mistake.  We ordered the Bolani as an appetizer (Leek & potato-filled pastries) but received the Kado Borani (Roasted squash topped with garlic yogurt in a flat bread) instead.  This was disappointing as we didn't really enjoy the Borani.  The squash was in large shavings and the taste was just bland - we both agreed it would have been better pureed and baked as a bread filling.  The entrees we ordered were the Bodinjon Borani (eggplant) and the Lamb Kabob - both were pretty good.  The 6 chunks of lamb I got were juicy and had a good amount of flavor on its own, and the fresh pepper/cilantro sauces on the side were a nice addition.  It was $17 for the 6 chunks of lamb, and I typically eat about 1/4 of my rice.  Of what I had, the rice was cooked well, but not exceptional.  We had to ask for the complimentary flatbread on the side - it came with our dish, but the server was too busy and overlooked it.  

If these hole-in-the-wall restaurants just added one more server, service would turn from subpar to exemplary and everyone would leave happy.  As it is, the food was good, but we did a whole bunch of waiting around eating it AND paying for it.  3.5 star experience and I'm looking forward to comparing it with the other Afghani place nearby.
author: Ben K.

description:
When I lived down the street from this place I'd stop in after work nearly weekly. Now I live on the opposite side of the lake and don't ge in much anymore. But this place is great!
Go for the "Brown Rice". They put some flavors n there that will ROCK your world, and ask for the almond and raisin topping... forget what it's called but it's FANTASTIC!
author: Michael F.

description:
uhm, yes.


Screw trekking it down to the FiDi and standing in line for the Halal Cart, seriously. I will trudge my way over here and sit my happy a$$ down for this food! It's a small hole in the wall joint with only 7 tables. 

I had the beef & chicken kabob combo for lunch. It totaled a little over $15 and that can be pricey for lunch (especially given the area) but I figure hey - there isn't a ton of this food in the area so they can get away with it. 
I'm not a fan of chicken. I only recently started eating it. The thing I hate most about chicken is how dry it is. At De Afghanan the chicken kebobs were so juicy I didn't care. The beef had a beautiful slightly smokey charred grilled exterior and the chunks were done medium rare - perfection.

De Afghanan is LEGIT. Kabobs are juicy, tender, and full of flavor. Even the rice is good on its own. Usually people smother yogurt and hot sauce all over but man... The food here doesn't need it, trust me on this one. 


P.S. The complimentary shornakhod (potatoes and garbanzo beans in a spicy chutney) are super spicy. They aren't lying. BUT IT'S DAMN GOOD.

HALAL BACK YOUNGIN HOO HOOO!
author: Susy C.

description: This place was so delicious. We ordered the combo plate and the specialty lamb plate. The meat is so tender and full of flavor. One of the best kabobs in SF. We also ordered the bolani for our appetizer which was more than enough for 2 people. So good food, good portions and the service was great. Will def be back!
author: Sandra S.

description:
This place is going to be the talk of the town very, very soon- it doesn't even matter that it's in the Tenderloin. Once people start finding out about it, there are going to be lines outside waiting to eat here.
The Bolani is a must- I got the one with pumpkin and it was so good! I probably could have eaten a few more of those by myself. It is a thin flatbread stuffed with thin slices of pumpkin and it also came with a yogurt sauce. So good.
The Triple Kabob Combo was very filling- you can definitely share it with another person. It comes with three chunks of chicken, three chunks of tekka beef, and a good sized chapli patty- all on top of challow (white) and pallow (brown) rice and a side of veggie salad. It also came with a basket of bread. Loved everything on the plate.
The service was friendly and the wait time was reasonable- knowing that your food is being freshly grilled is a great way to wait for your meal. This restaurant is legit and I'll definitely be coming back soon.
author: Grace L.

description: I try to come here at least once a week because it is so damn good. Chaplee kabob with rice and bread is to die for. I could eat here everyday. Service is great and the food comes out quick.
author: Darius A.

description: I came across with this Establishment while waiting for my Bus to arrived.. Never ate afghan food .. Took my chances late afternoon..Ordered to go the combo kebab .. Chicken N Beef with bismati rice.. .. IT'S AWESOME! !! Never regretted coming over..Beef's Soo tender And the Chicken was perfect.. I work out n don't eat Rice.. But after I tasted a few!! I finished it all.. The green spicy beans was good too.. Verdict?? I'd be back here n order to Go.. Place is home style.. The Lady who I talked too was nice enough To explain what's afghan food is .. It's a learning experience .. I'd recommend it !!!
author: Donovan L.

description:
Perfect comfort food. 
Excellent service.
A must try. 
Enjoy! 

Especially you must try the Dough. A very unique drink.
author: Payman N.

description: my boyfriend & i ate here last night and it was delicious. the service was great. i literally had no complaints after and was in love! i has the combination plate with beef and chicken kabob and he had the lamb kabob. my boyfriend tried some of my chicken but not the beef and he's not sick, so i'm assuming the beef was undercooked or spoiled meat. it was the last thing i ate last night and i woke up this morning throwing up violently. i had the WORST food poisoning i've ever had! i loved everything about this place but sadly my experience afterwards was horrible to say the least. eat here at your own risk
author: Nneka M.

description: Had a dinner there the other night and highly recomend to order lassi and the cubed grilled meat! We had multiple items but the meat was outsnding!
author: Anelya S.

description: All good, but portions size surprised us. We were expecting sizes to be little more than what we got. Other than that food was good. My mom really liked it.
author: Poorak K.

description: I love the Bolani and all the Kabobs. Service was great as well.
author: Meez A.

description:
Wow. So flavorful. Simply outstanding. Can't wait for dinner tomorrow night... too long to wait to come again.

The Borani Kadoo (pumpkin appetizer) was delicious. The triple kabob was tender, wonderfully spiced, and enough to feed a small village. 

Really outstanding food!
author: Rusty A.

description: I've been here multiple times, in person and I've gotten carry out. I've never been disappointed. This is probably the best afghan food in the city. The chicken is probably my favorite, it's always done to perfection. I see why this place is so highly rated, they obviously know what they're doing.
author: Omar A.

description: Terrible food terrible service. You order a 3 item combo and they give you two items. When you complain about it they accuse you of lying. Or they say the delivery driver at your food. Either way this is bad business and if a random person is eating your food while they're driving it's not sanitary. Don't eat here.
author: Jovon I.

description:
Wow! Really great meal. If you're in the mood for some authentic middle eastern dishes, come here!

I had their famous kabob, served with grilled vegetables and a handful of rice. A side of a grilled tomato and onions as well to add flavor, and that mysterious powder that is common in the Mediterranean diet (it's kind of burgundy and granular, and has a sour taste). Me and the BF had the yogurt drink which was ice cold and refreshing! 

Sadly, we didn't have time for dessert because we had to catch a movie, but I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Ariel S.

description:
I'd say my party of 5 was very lucky to snag the only open table one hour before they closed.  After we sat, the waiter had to turn away other late comers since the restaurant wouldn't be able to accommodate them.  Anyways, we had a few beers and appetizers elsewhere so we only ordered communal dishes for everyone to share.

For starters, we ordered the bolani.  Bolani reminds me of naan but with potato filling accompanied by white yogurt sauce.  It's a great appetizer dish but for our case, it went rather well with the alcohol in our stomachs.

For mains, we shared the lamb kebob and the chicken, beef, and chaplee combo.  Let me start by saying how great the rice are.  There's two different types: white and brown.  While I cannot tell the difference, I can say that the rice were not oily like other restaurants.  The chicken was semi-moist but the beef and lamb were just right.  Overall, a great solid place to fulfill your Mediterranean cravings.
author: Ronald L.

description: If you've never tried Afghan food then you are missing out. If you haven't tried this Afghan Restaurant then you are crazy!
author: Masood F.

description:
Decided to stop here for lunch since I'm in LOVE with their other location in Fremont, which I often grace with my presence, and am glad I did.

We ordered the mantu, bolani (1/2 pumpkin, 1/2 potato/green onion), lamb kabob, and beef teka kabob. 

The bolani was delicious! (Even slightly better than the bolani I've had at the Fremont location.) Arrived hot and was nice and crisp on the outside without being dry or tough. Both fillings were delicious, though the potato and green onion was a bit on the spicy side (we decided on medium heat), so if spicy food is not your thing, go for mild. 

My favorite dish is the beef teka kabob, hands down, and I always order this dish! I like mine done medium rare. The kebobs are juicy, perfectly seasoned, and taste wonderfully beefy. Served alongside rice (you can choose between plain white basmati or the flavored rice) and a small serving of salad. This is one dish I never refuse! The lamb kabobs are also delicious, but I'm slightly biased towards beef. :)

However, I do think their portions are smaller than the restaurant in Fremont, and as for the ambiance and service, nothing special.
author: Adeeba A.

description:
Food is good but service is awful and thisrespect. 

Went for lunch with my Friend today and felt totally disrespected. we ordered a Chapli kabob and Qabuli Palawo, 
The waiter was so mean he had very bad attitude, ununformed he was looked like he is in GYM, horrible and that's why they get one star.  
No apology 
Really bad service and this was our second visit and had liked the food here but with service like this not planning to return.
author: Sayed F.

description:
For the price, this place is outrageous! The meat is the right amount of tender and has an incredible clean taste and feel to it that mirrors the cleanliness of their establishment. Well run and with friendly servers, this place is that hole in the wall you accidentally stumble into and immediately become a regular.

All the kabobs are great, as well as their sides and bolani. The chapli kabob is my favorite and the sheer chai complements it nicely on a cold day. And the food is very cheap for San Francisco, especially given the massive quantities served. Highly recommended to all.
author: Kurt B.

description:
Delicious food.   Casual dining.  Excellent service.  So so good!!!!
I ordered the combo which consisted of chicken kabob and two kinds of beef kabob and asked to trade one out for lamb.  The meal came with rice and veggies. I also had the yogurt drink to go with the meal.  The meat was so flavorful and tender.  The rice - perfectly cooked and delicious.  Highly recommend trying this place if you love Middle Eastern/Mediterranean food.
author: Viktoria R.

description:
Ok I was really sad that sf's best burrito closed down and I couldn't have anymore of Juan's burritos but this is a wonderful replacement. 

They really spruced the place up and it has a delightful atmosphere. The service is great and the owner (I'm assuming) is super nice! Also, you no longer have to walk through the kitchen to get to the bathroom anymore. 

Anyhow, on to the food. Delicious. The kebabs are so moist it's amazing. Hard to believe that it's chicken breast as I've never had it this moist. I've also had the lamb shank and that was so tender I didn't even need the knife. However texture isn't everything. This place really takes it to another level with the flavor. Delicately spiced but strong at the same time. Does that even make sense? 

I've only had one bad thing and it was the noodle soup, it was way too sour for my taste, but hey, it may float someone else's boat. 

Definitely come by and check it out.
author: Tu T.

description:
Hot damn, these folks make nice kabobs. 

I ordered the beef and chicken combo and was chewing like a giddy birthday girl -and it wasn't even my birthday! The chicken is mysteriously moist and succulent in a way that I'm unaccustomed. It was awesome! The beef was good too. All with two kinds of rice, which just rocks my world because I love rice. 

Someone ordered the mantoo and I forgot what else people ordered. We all cleared our plates. One of my homegirls also practically drank the cilantro chutney. It was pretty good and she was all over it like a coupon clipper with the Sunday paper :)

Our gentleman friend got us started with some bolani and we loved it. Almost as much as him. 

A plate of baklava appeared at the end of our meal. I don't know where it came from but it certainly didn't last. Good stuff.

Service was great, location was great, people were great, and the food was great. I can't believe I haven't been here before!

I'll be back.
author: Loli L.

description: Amazing food! Amazing service. Great wait staff. Feels like a clean and cozy hole in the wall. Highly recommended. Good prices. Try the rice dessert.
author: Julian C.

description:
The food was good.  I've never had Afghan food and I found the chicken and lamb kebobs to be very tasty.

It's quite rare to go to a restaurant and the service is just as good as the food.  This was not one of those places.  

The moment we entered the restaurant, a woman was busy on the phone probably taking a food order, which is fine.  However, after her call, she immediately turned and went to the back if the restaurant.  We stood there wondering...do we seat ourselves? Do we get our own menus? After standing there, looking around like idiots, we found a table.  Minor note...the restaurant was empty except for a family sitting in a corner. They must've known the woman because they were quite friendly and these people were walking around like they knew the proprietor.  Anyway, after we sat down, she must've realized, 'gee, I wonder what happened to the people who were standing inside the middle of the restaurant for 5 minutes'? She said to us, oh, you found a seat and have menus already? Are you freakin' kidding me?!

All I can say is...go for the food not the service.
author: O ..

description: Delicious! We got the combo and chicken platter and they were both delicious. Portions are very big too! Small inside but you can take out.
author: S K.

description: I can't think of anything bad to say about this place.  The food was good, service great and the place was cozy and nice.  If I had to complain about one thing is that the parking sucks but they have no control over that.  Try this place out!  I will return!
author: Don A.

description: I'm disappointed!!! I called them to know if they were open because on yelp showing closed . A man picked up the phone, he was so rude to me. He didn't even give a proper answer. Please have some respect and be nice when you answer the phone!!!
author: Sherzodbek M.

description:
This place is awesome. The food is simply incredible, perfectly seasoned and generous portions.

The rice is amazing, mainly the brown one. And do yourself a favor, order the lamb kebab. It is a party in your mouth.

The place is very casual. It is that little place that you always go back on your neighborhood. Perfect for lunch with co-workers or for a night that you don't feel like cooking.
author: Rafael F.

description:
A life changing experience.
Here's the breakdown:

Service: 5/5 the manager makes you feel as though you are old friends. I always feel like I'm being invited into someone's home to eat as opposed to being at a restaurant. Kitchen is speedy, and the wait staff seems to be quite on the ball.

Food: 5/5 lamb is amazing, rice is amazing, bolani is amazing, meat kabobs are amazing. Haven't had a bad thing from this menu yet. I would recommend asking your waiter about what is good, they have great suggestions based on what you're in the mood for.

Venue: 5/5 very nice decor with artwork on all of the walls. Clean place, every table gets a set of sauces, which is awesome.

Scalability: 4/5 not a super large place, you may need to wait for a table during busy hours.

Cost: 5/5 this place is moderately priced, and in my opinion delivers food that is better than it costs.

Overall: 5/5 such good food and service! I've been back multiple times and had a consistently good experience. I'll be back again soon.
author: Paul P.

description: Loved this place! Never knew this gem existed right in the heart of SF!
author: Ed K.

description: So delicious, it was my first time eating Afghan food. For sure I'll be back again. They had another place next to it its belong to them with the same name for fast orders.
author: Mohamed A.

description:
Best kabobs I've ever had - chicken was not dry at all and the beef and ground beef was full of flavor...and I normally don't like beef! 

The appetizers were ok - we had the bolani with pumpkin and the dumplings. Good but the kabobs are what really shine and what we would go back for. 

Loved the chutney as well. Portions are big so good value too.
author: Becca W.

description:
I had the sambussa, the special Kifto and the Telba. All were delicious. Good service as well!
Recommended ^_^
author: Shay W.

description:
Wow.   This is truly delicious and legit Afgan food (sorry Helmand).  Great for lunch or dinner...

Kebabs and Bolani katchaloo were terrific.   And the homemade sauces and salad were even better than their Fremont location :)
author: Pink ..

description:
Fantastic! 
Kebab , rice pullow w/lamb shank, baked pumpkin, bolani (similar to Indonesian martabak) were all excellent.
author: Rennie S.

description: Ordered to go. Food took about an hour to arrive. We went for the quabili pallow and the chicken kabob. Both were really good and are highly recommended.
author: Sol V.

description:
So. Much. Flavor. 

The food in this hole in the wall joint is absolutely delicious. 

I tried the chicken kabob and the lamb kabob and although they were both great, the lamb definitely beats the chicken on flavor. 

They also offer complimentary bread and shornakhod (garbanzo beans and potatoes with spicy cilantro chutney), which are both quite tasty. 

Don't go for the atmosphere or service - go for the food.
author: Juliana K.

description:
We stopped in here in advance of seeing Ghost Busters at the AMC around the block.   It's not a very big resturant.  And with the food sooo delicious, be prepared for a wait.  But it's worth the wait.  

Did I say how delicious the food is?  We had the lamb kabab. I'm not a big lamb eater, unless I'm in a Muslim resturant who generally know how to cook it best.  The lamb here was so juicy and tender. 

And be sure to check out their chai!  

As to service, they had just one waiter for a full house, but she was on the ball, even though rushed.  And she was very helpful in guiding us as newbies on their menu.  We are definitely coming back here.
author: Fog F.

description: Haven't visit place itself, ordered delivery for the company bash. Many people stated that never eat so good-testing kebab. Balanced spices and marinades make lamb perfect. The chicken kebob was awesome as well, the yellow-colored marinade has unique test, not sure what they used. Rice and yougurst were well balanced as well. Five stars.
author: Oleg O.

description: Yum yum yum!!! Service is great! Atmosphere is great! Food is incredible!!! The beef teka is amazing!!! We cannot wait to come back again! Everything was great.
author: Mallory R.

description:
Great food, and friendly staff. I've tried several Afghan restaurant in the US and Canada, nobody makes the Bolani like this place does. 
It would be great if they expanded their delivery service to at least 3 mile radius, with all the food items included. Currently their delivery/pick up menu on eat 24 lacks ALL the items in their menu.
author: Monica R B.

description:
Food is alright if you ever get it S and I went for dinner, the place is very small, about 8 tables, and two waiters. We ordered two veggie dishes to share, rice and bread. One dish came out reasonably quickly but really needed to be eaten with bread or rice. No bread, no rice. 15 mins elapse. Waiter swings by and leaves empty drink glasses on the table, not asking if we'd like water but inquiring to us if the rest of our food had come out. It had not. Another 10-15 mins elapse, the waiter came by, left to the empties again, and once again asked us if the rest of our food has come out. The rest of the food comes out about 5 minutes later, we finished the first dish without bread and rice since it's basically gotten cold by now. The waiter still hasn't cleared our empties, and our tiny table is getting cramped. 


Food was good, service is awful. Skip this location which lacks all atmosphere and go to the Fremont location instead for a much better experience.
author: Jared Z.

description: I've ordered take out here twice. Both times the food is absolutely amazing. The Kababs are out of this world. The Bolani is incredible and the Mantus is the best I've ever had. If you enjoy Afghani food this place is by far the best in San Francisco. If you haven't tried Afghani food then start here. It's a hidden gem right on Geary Street and Van Ness. It has a nice Family feel to it and I'm looking forward to eating there sometime soon.
author: Kevin C.

description: I just love coming here. The food is always as well as the service! The kabobs are perfectly marinated and very tasteful. The bolani is always made so tasty and with the yogurt it's the perfect duo! You can never go wrong with anything you order from here. I love everything on the menu and I've tried everything!
author: Jamie D.

description:
I love this gem.

BYOB. Get the chicken kabob and the lamb. Eggplant app is also good. 

The green spicy sauce is so delicious. Put it on everything!
author: Jessica K.

description: Really extraordinary food!  I'm only taking off a star because the delivery service is so comically bad.  I basically had to go for a 5 minute walk to find my driver, which is fine because why not? If you want speedy, efficient delivery in San Francisco, unfortunately you won't find it unless you pay a fortune and order through a Postmate or courier.  But I digress.
author: Thomas P.

description: Most authentic, flavorful afghan food you'll ever eat in a restaurant. Aush is a must. Kabobs are THE best.
author: Aryan R.

description: This place is a gem.  I had the lamb shank with rice, shornakhod, and the sabzi.  All were absolutely delicious.  Their menu is eclectic and I'll definitely be back to try everything else on it especially the delicious looking kabobs.  My review is for the food and service alone.  The decor is nothing special and inedible so never really a deal breaker in my book.  It's BYOB, good thing there is a convenience store 1 block away.
author: Scott S.

description:
Food: 4
Decor: 3
Service: 3

Been here twice with groups of 4.

1. Bolani
Leek & potato-filled pastries baked on a flat pan served with yogurt and cilantro chutney half order Bolani
~Pretty good. Yogurt had a nice kick to it.

2. Kado Borani
Roasted squash topped with garlic yogurt, dry mint and served with Afghan bread
~Pretty good.

3. Triple Chicken, Beef & Chapli kebab
~Pretty good. Proteins all cooked quite well, and I liked the rice and salad. Didn't care for the green onions on top though.

Service was mediocre. Seemed understaffed, and we had to flag a server several times.
author: David L.

description:
This is a truly special place.  Wonderful food and even more wonderful hosts. The 
I have some limiting diet restrictions that for some reason are difficult for Sf people to get right. I don't eat grain or raw chicken. 

Well it was no problem at this place. The server was warm an completely accommodating. She even offered to bring out extra salad. 
And the food was so good.  
My BF and I shared the sabzi, bodinjon borani, and the Chicken, Beef & Chapli combo. 
Sabzi looks Indian saag but tastes  even better. Ridiculously good. 
The meat is why we came and were not disappointed. Tender, perfectly cooked and delicious seasonings 
Finally a place in SF that gets everything right.
author: Corey Jace W.

description: Stumbled up the Kebab House whilst traipsing around the city. Loved the perfectly spiced and perfectly cooked kebabs. I had the lamb and meat kebabs. Ethnic food at its best. Simple, flavorful and authentic. Staff is friendly and efficient.
author: Chris T.

description: I crave this place almost every week. The combination plate is so savory and filled with spices. The Bolani is a great appetizer too!
